tweet: On #TransDayofVisibility, we reaffirm our commitment to stand beside our trans loved ones, friends, neighbors, fellow Americans & those around the world as we fight together for full equality and demand a better, freer and just society for us all.

I will continue to fight to protect New Hampshire’s role in our national security and ease the uncertainty that the President’s declaration has caused at the Shipyard. pic.twitter.com/VLAI8eM78P

Let’s be clear: The administration is raiding funding that Congress allocated without telling us or the public. We’ve had to repeatedly press for the list of military construction projects potentially impacted by the declaration.

It makes no sense to take money from construction projects at the Shipyard that will keep our nation’s submarines in service to pay for a wall that candidate Trump promised Mexico would pay for. If Mexico isn’t paying for it, New Hampshire shouldn’t have to pick up the tab.

I appreciate Assistant Secretary Guerts’ testimony in support of the critical work the Shipyard and its employees perform in the defense of our country, but they need assurance that their mission will not be undermined.

Today, I questioned Navy leadership on the potential harmful impact of the President’s emergency declaration on the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HO1uHqlOUYA&feature=youtu.be …
She is representing the U.S. interest in making sure our foreign assistance is used wisely and that Ukraine continues to stand against Russian aggression.

The U.S. plays a critical role in helping Ukraine stand against both external and internal threats. Ambassador Yovanovitch has been a strong voice for the U.S. in this effort & she is right to call those out who undermine efforts to combat corruption in Ukraine.
It’s time to stop playing political games and work across the aisle to tackle this crisis.

The science is crystal clear on climate change, which is why Congress needs to act. The #GreenNewDeal has helped start an important debate, however it doesn’t change the law or establish new programs.

For instance, Republican leadership have consistently blocked my bipartisan energy efficiency legislation, despite the fact that it would create nearly 200,000 jobs and reduce carbon emissions equivalent to taking 22 million cars off the road.

I’m deeply disappointed that Republican leadership are only allowing a vote on the #GreenNewDeal for political purposes, and are not allowing a real debate on legislation that’s been introduced to combat the effects of climate change and invest in sustainable solutions.
The President should be working with Congress to lower costs and expand coverage, not unravel all the progress we’ve made.

The American people have made it abundantly clear that they don’t want their health care coverage taken away, so why is the Trump administration still demanding health care repeal? This is cruel and senseless.

The Trump admin is now arguing in federal court that the ACA should be struck down in its entirety – Marketplace coverage, Medicaid expansion, pre-existing condition protections, coverage on parents’ insurance, improvements to Medicare Rx drug coverage – all of it. https://twitter.com/washingtonpost/status/1110378997031071744 …
Let's talk, @JimBridenstine. https://twitter.com/guardian/status/1110349516660711431 …

My bipartisan bill, the Global HER Act, would permanently repeal this unwarranted and cruel policy – I urge congressional leadership in both chambers to allow a vote immediately. 
 https://www.shaheen.senate.gov/news/press/shaheen-lowey-lead-bipartisan-bicameral-push-to-permanently-repeal-the-global-gag-rule …

I have requested more information from the administration about its latest policy against women and girls and am committed to working in a bipartisan manner to ensure that women are not taken further back after making hard-fought gains through the years.

Often times, the groups that the administration is targeting are the only health providers for the most vulnerable populations – restricting their ability to deliver services to women and children around the globe.
Instead, the Trump administration’s actions threaten access to critical services that prevent maternal deaths, treat HIV and Zika, and provide communities with lifesaving health care.

While Secretary Pompeo’s announcement was not accompanied by any sort of plan for implementation, his announcement signifies a further expansion of a policy that puts women’s lives at risk around the world and has proven not to achieve its stated aim of reducing abortions.
That is unconscionable.

The admin's obsession w/attacking women’s repro health is egregious & dangerous. Further expanding the Global Gag Rule puts international organizations in an impossible position: provide women the full scope of repro health care services or deny critical funding that saves lives. https://twitter.com/Reuters/status/1110557505069989894 …

Today, the House will vote to block President Trump’s declaration that threatens funding for the Shipyard to pay for the border wall. I urge more Republicans to join this bipartisan effort. The declaration is a threat to local jobs, the Shipyard's mission and national security. pic.twitter.com/Z2Gqah0Ohu

I look forward to questioning Attorney General Barr on the report when he comes before the Senate, and will continue to urge him to make the full report available to the American public so they can reach their own conclusions.
This report could have serious implications for our national security – there is no excuse for not disclosing all the facts and keeping its details secret.

We know Russia interfered in our election and that Special Counsel Mueller has brought nearly 200 charges against 34 individuals and 3 companies, including 6 former Trump officials and 26 Russian nationals.
After a nearly two-year investigation, a four-page summary on Russia’s assault on our electoral system is woefully insufficient.

This report could have serious national security implications and the American people should be allowed to see it in its entirety so they can make their own judgments about its content. https://twitter.com/ABC/status/1109199540123504646 …

I’ll continue to make the case to military leadership that PNSY priorities must be taken off the list of threatened projects and will continue to explore all means to block this “emergency” declaration from impacting NH.
If Mexico isn’t paying for the wall, New Hampshire shouldn’t have to cover the tab.

Candidate Trump made it clear that taxpayers wouldn’t foot the bill for his wall – and when he was in NH, he certainly didn’t tell voters that taxpayer funds set aside for the Shipyard would be threatened.

As a member of the Armed Services & Appropriations Committees, I fought for these projects & worked to get the funding signed into law. Raiding this funding for his border wall is unconstitutional & disingenuous.
Let’s be clear: this is no longer a theoretical threat to our Shipyard and our regional economy. The DOD’s list of potential projects includes more than $224 million in Shipyard priorities.

The President’s “emergency” declaration jeopardizes NH jobs, the Shipyard’s mission & our national security – all to fund his border wall that he repeatedly promised Mexico would pay for. And now we know 4 projects at PNSY are on the chopping block.

.@SenatorHassan, @RepChrisPappas & I just sat down with Portsmouth Naval Shipyard leadership and local union reps to discuss the significant funding threats to PNSY due to the President’s “emergency” declaration. pic.twitter.com/0IDMgu7T5x

Providing treatment to those who desperately need it and continuing to get resources to law enforcement and first responders is fundamental to tackling this crisis. This is why working across the aisle is so critical to getting help to states like NH.

It’s important that we never become numb to the scale of the opioid crisis. Every death is a heartbreaking loss.
These resources will help save lives and by continuing to work across the aisle, we can build on the progress we’ve made in this year’s budget process.

Every life lost to an overdose is a tremendous tragedy and New Hampshire remains one of the states hardest hit by this crisis, which is why I’ve fought to make sure our state is prioritized in the funding process.

SAMHSA just announced an additional $12M from legislation Congress passed last year to fight the opioid epidemic in NH, made possible by the bipartisan budget agreement negotiated in Congress. These funds are very welcome news & can immediately be put to use in our state.

I will continue to work to bring this legislation to the floor for a vote. We need to hold these companies accountable and come together to protect the next generation.

Kids who vape are more likely to smoke tobacco and develop lifelong nicotine addiction. I introduced the E-cigarette Youth Protection Act, which would require e-cigarette companies to help fund prevention efforts, including outreach to young people on the health risks of vaping.
E-cigarette use is skyrocketing among young people. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 1 in 5 high school students used e-cigarettes last year, up from 1 in 100 in 2011.
Today, I joined students from Dover Youth to Youth, school administrators, health experts and city officials at Dover High School to discuss the youth vaping crisis. pic.twitter.com/5vj6F5EwKT

I will not stand idly by while funding is threatened for the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard and the New Hampshire National Guard, and will continue do everything in my power to protect New Hampshire’s role in our national security.
Candidate Trump promised that Mexico would pay for the wall – he never mentioned raiding taxpayer funds dedicated to the military.
I’m very pleased that the Senate was able to act in a bipartisan way to defend the Constitution and protect resources that have been allocated by Congress to support our armed forces.

A college education should be within reach of all qualified students, no matter their financial resources. I will continue to advocate for programs that support students and make college more affordable.

The President’s budget would make significant cuts to programs that ease the burden of student loan debt and help young people from low-income families cover the cost of tuition, books and other educational expenses. https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2019/03/12/white-house-wants-12-percent-cut-education-spending …
Student debt is crippling families in New Hampshire. Our state ranks among the highest in both average debt per graduate and in the proportion of graduates leaving school with debt.

Securing these visas for Afghan interpreters has been a top national security priority & I was honored to work w/ Senator John McCain on this issue. As we mark 10 years of the SIV program, we reaffirm our commitment to uphold our nation’s promise to protect these brave civilians.

10 years ago today the Special Immigrant Visa (SIVs) program was established. This program is critical to our national defense & honors the tremendous risk and sacrifice of interpreters who stand shoulder-to-shoulder with U.S. troops & diplomats.

As Congress begins our important work to fund the government this year, I’ll be fighting to make sure additional opioid response funding is signed into law and that New Hampshire gets its fair share to help the state continue to battle this epidemic.

I also strongly oppose proposals to cut Medicaid Expansion & gut the ACA. Taken together, these actions could increase health care costs for thousands in NH, decrease access to opioid treatment & allow insurance companies to discriminate against those w/ pre-existing conditions.
With hundreds of Granite Staters still dying every year, this is not the time to be withdrawing help from our local law enforcement and community partners who are stretched thin by the opioid crisis.

I’m pleased the President’s budget proposal continues opioid treatment funding @SenatorHassan & I helped secure, but I’m deeply concerned about cuts to programs that help NH law enforcement & community organizations on the front lines of the epidemic.

This mirrors the successful efforts to reduce teen smoking of standard cigarettes. Read more:  https://www.shaheen.senate.gov/news/press/as-youth-e-cigarette-use-skyrockets-shaheen-introduces-bill-that-requires-e-cigarette-manufacturers-to-fund-prevention-efforts …

My bill would force e-cig companies to pay fees that would fund regulation enforcement, including those that are designed to protect young people, and awareness campaigns, to set the record straight about e-cigs.

I appreciate @SGottliebFDA’s  work on limiting teen access to flavored e-cigarettes & and I hope that the next Commissioner of the FDA will build on these initial efforts. Congress also has a role to play here and I’ve introduced legislation to confront this crisis.

Yet, this youth e-cig crisis didn’t start by accident. E-cig manufacturers, like Juul, aggressively marketed their product to young people by using cutting edge targeting on social media: https://www.vox.com/2019/1/25/18194953/vape-juul-e-cigarette-marketing …

The Surgeon General warns that nicotine, regardless of delivery device, “can cause addiction and can harm the developing adolescent brain. ” It’s also linked to liver & lung damage, increased heart rate & blood pressure, insulin resistance & type 2 diabetes in chronic use cases.

What’s more? Research is showing that teens who use e-cigarettes are more likely to progress to smoking traditional cigarettes: https://truthinitiative.org/research/using-e-cigarettes-increases-likelihood-using-cigarettes-among-youth-study-finds …
And in just one year (2017-2018), e-cig use among high schoolers rose by 78%! https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/67/wr/mm6745a5.htm …

This is a trend experienced across the country w/ nearly 21% of high school students nationally now reporting using e-cigarettes. And this problem is by no means limited to high schools—just under 5% of middle schoolers report using a vaping device.

This is why teen vaping is a crisis: In NH, nearly 24% of high school teens report having recently used an e-cigarette and 41% say they’ve tried it. Just over 50% of 12th graders have tried a vaping device.  https://www.education.nh.gov/instruction/school_health/documents/nhyrbsresultsgraphs.pdf …

Our bill – the PFAS Action Act – would help us achieve those goals to ensure families can trust the water they drink in NH & across the nation. Read more here:  https://www.shaheen.senate.gov/news/press/shaheen-hassan-and-bipartisan-group-of-senators-introduce-pfas-action-plan-of-2019 … https://twitter.com/SenatorShaheen/status/1101597007867719680 …

That’s why I worked w/ a bipartisan group of Senators to introduce legislation to designate PFAS chemicals as hazardous substances under our environmental protection laws. We need to address contamination, increase transparency & hold responsible parties accountable.

NH families shouldn’t have to worry about the safety of their drinking water every time they turn on the tap. As the nationwide PFAS health impact study moves forward, Congress must keep working & take steps to ensure our environment and water supplies are clean.
